projects.description: I started out learning JavaScript syntax and data structures by building a Random Quote Generator, a program that displays a randomly selected quote each time the user clicks a button.

Displaying a large amount of data on a web page, like a list of 200 movie titles or 400 products, can overwhelm a user with too much information at once. A common solution is to create separate “pages” that each display a small portion of the data. In my second project, I used JavaScript to display several “pages” of student data that the user can easily navigate and view.

Full Stack JavaScript developers create forms to collect information from users for nearly every website and application they build. For this project, I used what I have learned to enhance a form so that it’s engaging, interactive, and easy to use.

A browser-based, word guessing game: 'Phrase Hunter'. I used JavaScript and OOP (Object-Oriented Programming) to select a random, hidden phrase. A player tries to guess the phrase by selecting individual letters from an onscreen keyboard. Can they guess the phrase before they run out of attempts?

Many sites — Twitter, Facebook, IMDB, and Wikipedia to name a few — offer a vast sea of data that you can access and display on your own web pages. Using JavaScript, I created an employee directory by communicating with a third-party API (Application Programming Interface).
